articles.title: Inside the mysterious collapse of dark matter halos
articles.summary: Physicists have unveiled a new way to simulate a mysterious form of dark matter that can collide with itself but not with normal matter. This self-interacting dark matter may trigger a dramatic collapse inside dark matter halos, heating and densifying their cores in surprising ways. Until now, this crucial middle ground of behavior was nearly impossible to model accurately. The new code makes these simulations faster, more precise, and accessible enough to run on a laptop.
articles.content:
For nearly 100 years, dark matter has remained one of the biggest unanswered questions in cosmology. Although it cannot be seen directly, its gravitational influence shapes galaxies and the large-scale structure of the universe. At the Perimeter Institute, two physicists are investigating how a particular form of dark matter, known as self-interacting dark matter (SIDM), may influence the way cosmic structures grow and change over time.

In research published in Physical Review Letters, James Gurian and Simon May introduce a new computational tool designed to study how SIDM affects galaxy formation. Their approach makes it possible to explore types of particle interactions that were previously difficult or impractical to model accurately.

When Dark Matter Interacts With Itself

SIDM is a theoretical form of dark matter whose particles can collide with one another but do not interact with baryonic matter, the familiar matter made of protons, neutrons, and electrons. These collisions conserve energy through what physicists call elastic self-interactions. This behavior can strongly influence dark matter halos, the massive concentrations of dark matter that surround galaxies and help guide their evolution.

"Dark matter forms relatively diffuse clumps which are still much denser than the average density of the universe," says Gurian, a Perimeter postdoctoral fellow and co-author of the study. "The Milky Way and other galaxies live in these dark matter halos."

Heat, Energy Flow, and Core Collapse

The self-interacting nature of SIDM can trigger a process known as gravothermal collapse within dark matter halos. This phenomenon arises from a counterintuitive property of gravity, where systems bound by gravity become hotter as they lose energy rather than cooling down.

"You have this self-interacting dark matter which transports energy, and it tends to transport energy outwards in these halos," says Gurian. "This leads to the inner core getting really hot and dense as energy is transported outwards." Over time, this process can drive the core of the halo toward a dramatic collapse.

A Missing Link in Dark Matter Modeling

Simulating the structures formed by SIDM has long been a challenge. Existing methods work well only under certain conditions. Some simulations perform best when dark matter is sparse and collisions are rare, while others are effective only when dark matter is extremely dense and interactions are frequent.

"One approach is an N-body simulation approach that works really well when dark matter is not very dense and collisions are infrequent. The other approach is a fluid approach -- and this works when dark matter is very dense and collisions are frequent."

"But for the in-between, there wasn't a good method," Gurian says. "You need an intermediate range approach to correctly go between the low-density and high-density parts. That was the origin of this project."

A Faster and More Accessible Simulation Tool

To solve this problem, Gurian and his co-author Simon May, a former Perimeter postdoctoral researcher now serving as an ERC Preparative Fellow at Bielefeld University, developed a new code called KISS-SIDM. The software bridges the gap between existing simulation methods, delivering higher accuracy while requiring far less computing power. It is also publicly available for other researchers.

"Before, if you wanted to check different parameters for self-interacting dark matter, you needed to either use this really simplified fluid model, or go to a cluster, which is computationally expensive. This code is faster, and you can run it on your laptop," says Gurian.

Opening the Door to New Dark Matter Physics

Interest in interacting dark matter has grown in recent years, partly due to puzzling features seen in galaxies that may not fit standard models.

"There has been considerable interest recently in interacting dark matter models, due to possible anomalies detected in observations of galaxies that may require new physics in the dark sector," says Neal Dalal, a member of the Perimeter Institute research faculty.

"Previously, it was not possible to perform accurate calculations of cosmic structure formation in these sorts of models, but the method developed by James and Simon provides a solution that finally allows us to simulate the evolution of dark matter in models with significant interactions," Dalal says. "Their paper should enable a broad spectrum of studies that previously were intractable."

Implications for Black Holes and Beyond

The collapse of dark matter cores is especially intriguing because it may leave observable signatures, including possible connections to black hole formation. However, how this process ultimately ends remains an open question.

"The fundamental question is, what's the final endpoint of this collapse? That's what we'd really like to do -- study the phase after you form a black hole."

By making it possible to explore these extreme conditions in detail, the new code represents an important step toward answering some of the deepest questions about dark matter and the structure of the universe.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in modeling self-interacting dark matter, which has broad implications for understanding cosmic structure formation and potentially black hole formation. The new simulation tool is faster, more precise, accessible, and publicly available, enabling wide research impact and advancing fundamental knowledge about the universe.
articles.personality_title: New simulation tool reveals hidden behavior of dark matter in galaxies
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Dark matter is an invisible substance that makes up most of the matter in the universe. It shapes galaxies and cosmic structures by its gravity, but scientists do not fully understand how it behaves. One idea is that dark matter particles can sometimes collide with each other, a type called self-interacting dark matter (SIDM).

**What happened** – Two physicists, James Gurian and Simon May, created a new computer program called KISS-SIDM that can simulate how SIDM affects the formation and change of galaxies. This program works faster and more accurately than older methods and can even run on a regular laptop. It fills a gap in previous models that could only handle very rare or very frequent dark matter collisions, but not the middle range.

**Impact** – This new tool helps scientists understand a strange process where the center of dark matter clumps, called halos, can heat up and collapse in surprising ways. This process might be linked to how black holes form. Because the program is easier to use and open to everyone, many researchers can now study these cosmic mysteries more deeply.

**What's next step** – Researchers will use this simulation to explore what happens after the dark matter core collapses, including if and how black holes emerge. This could answer important questions about the universe’s structure and the role of dark matter.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new, accessible simulation code allows scientists to study how self-interacting dark matter changes galaxy halos and may lead to black hole formation.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un nouvel outil de simulation révèle le comportement caché de la matière noire dans les galaxies
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La matière noire est une substance invisible qui compose la majeure partie de la matière dans l'univers. Elle façonne les galaxies et les structures cosmiques grâce à sa gravité, mais les scientifiques ne comprennent pas encore totalement son comportement. Une idée est que les particules de matière noire peuvent parfois entrer en collision entre elles, un type appelé matière noire auto-interagissante (MNAI).

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Deux physiciens, James Gurian et Simon May, ont créé un nouveau programme informatique nommé KISS-SIDM qui peut simuler comment la MNAI influence la formation et l’évolution des galaxies. Ce programme est plus rapide et plus précis que les méthodes précédentes et peut fonctionner sur un ordinateur portable classique. Il comble une lacune des modèles anciens qui ne pouvaient gérer que des collisions très rares ou très fréquentes, mais pas les cas intermédiaires.

**Impact** – Ce nouvel outil aide les scientifiques à comprendre un phénomène étrange où le centre des amas de matière noire, appelés halos, peut chauffer et s’effondrer de façon surprenante. Ce processus pourrait être lié à la formation des trous noirs. Comme le programme est facile à utiliser et accessible à tous, de nombreux chercheurs peuvent maintenant étudier ces mystères cosmiques en profondeur.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs utiliseront cette simulation pour explorer ce qui se passe après l’effondrement du cœur de matière noire, notamment comment les trous noirs pourraient se former. Cela pourrait répondre à des questions importantes sur la structure de l’univers et le rôle de la matière noire.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un nouveau code de simulation accessible permet d’étudier comment la matière noire auto-interagissante modifie les halos galactiques et peut conduire à la formation de trous noirs.
articles.personality_title_es: Nueva herramienta de simulación revela el comportamiento oculto de la materia oscura en las galaxias
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La materia oscura es una sustancia invisible que constituye la mayor parte de la materia en el universo. Moldea las galaxias y las estructuras cósmicas con su gravedad, pero los científicos aún no entienden completamente cómo se comporta. Una idea es que las partículas de materia oscura a veces pueden chocar entre sí, un tipo llamado materia oscura auto-interactiva (MDOI).

**Qué pasó** – Dos físicos, James Gurian y Simon May, crearon un nuevo programa informático llamado KISS-SIDM que puede simular cómo la MDOI afecta la formación y el cambio de las galaxias. Este programa funciona más rápido y con mayor precisión que métodos anteriores y puede ejecutarse en una computadora portátil común. Llena un vacío en los modelos anteriores que solo podían manejar colisiones muy raras o muy frecuentes, pero no el rango intermedio.

**Impacto** – Esta nueva herramienta ayuda a los científicos a entender un proceso extraño donde el centro de los grupos de materia oscura, llamados halos, puede calentarse y colapsar de maneras sorprendentes. Este proceso podría estar relacionado con la formación de agujeros negros. Debido a que el programa es más fácil de usar y está disponible para todos, muchos investigadores pueden ahora estudiar estos misterios cósmicos más a fondo.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores usarán esta simulación para explorar qué sucede después del colapso del núcleo de materia oscura, incluyendo si y cómo se forman los agujeros negros. Esto podría responder preguntas importantes sobre la estructura del universo y el papel de la materia oscura.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Un nuevo código de simulación accesible permite a los científicos estudiar cómo la materia oscura auto-interactiva cambia los halos galácticos y puede llevar a la formación de agujeros negros.

articles.title: Star appears to have vanished in a failed supernova
articles.summary: It is theoretically possible for a particularly massive star to collapse in on itself to form a black hole rather than exploding in a supernova, and we might now have seen the process in action
articles.content:
It is theoretically possible for a particularly massive star to collapse in on itself to form a black hole rather than exploding in a supernova, and we might now have seen the process in action

An illustration of a failed supernova forming a black hole NASA, ESA, and P. Jeffries (STScI)

A massive star in a nearby galaxy that reached the end of its life appears to have vanished rather than blown up, forming a black hole in what astronomers think is a rare way.

The most common black holes in our galaxy begin as stars. When these stars explode in a supernova, they can leave behind a black hole. But it is thought that black holes can also form from stars that fail to go supernova, instead simply collapsing under their own mass and producing a black hole directly.

In 2024, Kishalay De at Columbia University in New York and his colleagues observed an unusually bright star called M31-2014-DS1 in the nearby galaxy Andromeda that was around 20 times as massive as our sun. The star appeared to grow briefly brighter in 2014, before becoming dramatically dimmer between 2017 and 2020. De and his colleagues thought this pattern of brightening and then fading matched predictions for a failed supernova producing a black hole, but there was no sign of the black hole itself, such as tell-tale X-ray radiation.

Now, De and his team have observed M31-2014-DS1 with the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) and the Chandra X-ray Observatory, finding a faint, red object where the star once was that is only around 8 per cent as bright as the original star and is shrouded in a cocoon of dust moving rapidly outwards. This fits with what astronomers think a failed supernova making a black hole would look like. De and his team declined to comment for this story because their research hasn’t been peer-reviewed yet.

In a separate study analysing the same JWST data, Emma Beasor at Liverpool John Moores University, UK, and her colleagues found that the case for M31-2014-DS1 undergoing a failed supernova that produced a black hole was murkier, and that the observations could just as easily be the result of two stars merging, which would also produce a small outburst followed by a dimming and lots of dust.

Free newsletter Sign up to Launchpad Bring the galaxy to your inbox every month, with the latest space news, launches and astronomical occurrences from New Scientist’s Leah Crane. Sign up to newsletter

“The predictions for what a failed supernova looks like overlap quite significantly with what we might expect from two stars colliding and producing loads of dust,” says Beasor.

However, both scenarios would still be exotic phenomena, she says. “We don’t see stars that fade this significantly very often.”

“In either explanation, this is exciting. The visible star really has gone away,” says Gerard Gilmore at the University of Cambridge. “For many years, searches for disappearing massive stars led to ambiguous results. Now, the full power of multi-wavelength time-domain astronomy is on show and making progress.”

The only surefire way to say whether a black hole has been formed is to identify X-ray radiation, says Gilmore, which can’t currently be seen at the location of M31-2014-DS1. However, being able to study the aftermath of a dimmed star with a powerful telescope like JWST will allow us to find out what happened, he says. “We are on the verge of discovering at least one of the final fates of massive stars, an amusingly Cheshire cat way to go.”

References: arXiv, DOI: 10.48550/arXiv.2601.0577 and DOI: 10.48550/arXiv.2601.05317
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific observation potentially confirming a rare cosmic event—a massive star collapsing directly into a black hole without a supernova explosion. This discovery advances our understanding of stellar evolution and black hole formation, which has broad implications for astrophysics and space science. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights the use of cutting-edge telescopes, indicating a meaningful breakthrough in space exploration.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers may have spotted a star vanish into a black hole without a supernova
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – When very big stars reach the end of their lives, they usually explode in a supernova, leaving behind a black hole. But scientists have long thought some stars might collapse directly into black holes without exploding.

**What happened** – In 2024, researchers noticed a bright star called M31-2014-DS1 in the nearby Andromeda galaxy. It got brighter briefly in 2014, then faded a lot between 2017 and 2020. Using the James Webb Space Telescope and Chandra X-ray Observatory, scientists found a faint, dusty object where the star was, much dimmer than before. This matches what they expect from a star that failed to explode and turned into a black hole.

**Impact** – This observation is important because it could be the first clear example of a star disappearing without a supernova. It helps scientists understand new ways black holes can form and shows how advanced telescopes can reveal rare cosmic events.

**What's next step** – Researchers will keep studying this spot to find X-ray signals that confirm a black hole is there. They will also check if the star’s disappearance might be from two stars merging instead. Future observations with powerful telescopes will help explain what really happened.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists may have witnessed a rare event where a massive star collapsed directly into a black hole without exploding, opening new insights into how stars end their lives.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les astronomes ont peut-être observé une étoile disparaître dans un trou noir sans supernova
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Lorsque des étoiles très grosses arrivent à la fin de leur vie, elles explosent généralement en supernova, laissant derrière elles un trou noir. Mais les scientifiques pensent depuis longtemps que certaines étoiles pourraient s'effondrer directement en trous noirs sans exploser.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – En 2024, des chercheurs ont remarqué une étoile brillante appelée M31-2014-DS1 dans la galaxie voisine d’Andromède. Elle est devenue plus brillante brièvement en 2014, puis a beaucoup diminué entre 2017 et 2020. Avec le télescope spatial James Webb et l'observatoire Chandra, les scientifiques ont trouvé un objet faible et poussiéreux à l’emplacement de l’étoile, beaucoup plus sombre qu’avant. Cela correspond à ce qu’ils attendent d’une étoile qui n’a pas explosé et s’est transformée en trou noir.

**Impact** – Cette observation est importante car elle pourrait être le premier exemple clair d’une étoile qui disparaît sans supernova. Elle aide les scientifiques à comprendre de nouvelles façons dont les trous noirs peuvent se former et montre comment les télescopes avancés peuvent révéler des événements cosmiques rares.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs continueront à étudier cet endroit pour trouver des signaux en rayons X qui confirmeraient la présence d’un trou noir. Ils vérifieront aussi si la disparition de l’étoile pourrait venir de la fusion de deux étoiles. Les futures observations avec des télescopes puissants aideront à expliquer ce qui s’est vraiment passé.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les scientifiques ont peut-être observé un événement rare où une étoile massive s’est effondrée directement en trou noir sans exploser, ouvrant de nouvelles pistes sur la fin de vie des étoiles.
articles.personality_title_es: Los astrónomos podrían haber visto una estrella desaparecer en un agujero negro sin supernova
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Cuando las estrellas muy grandes llegan al final de su vida, suelen explotar en una supernova y dejan un agujero negro. Pero los científicos han pensado durante mucho tiempo que algunas estrellas podrían colapsar directamente en agujeros negros sin explotar.

**Qué pasó** – En 2024, investigadores observaron una estrella brillante llamada M31-2014-DS1 en la galaxia cercana Andrómeda. La estrella se volvió más brillante brevemente en 2014, luego se apagó mucho entre 2017 y 2020. Usando el telescopio espacial James Webb y el Observatorio de rayos X Chandra, encontraron un objeto débil y polvoriento donde estaba la estrella, mucho más tenue que antes. Esto coincide con lo que esperan de una estrella que no explotó y se convirtió en un agujero negro.

**Impacto** – Esta observación es importante porque podría ser el primer ejemplo claro de una estrella que desaparece sin una supernova. Ayuda a los científicos a entender nuevas formas en que se forman los agujeros negros y muestra cómo los telescopios avanzados pueden revelar eventos cósmicos raros.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores seguirán estudiando este lugar para encontrar señales de rayos X que confirmen que hay un agujero negro. También revisarán si la desaparición de la estrella podría ser por la fusión de dos estrellas. Las observaciones futuras con telescopios potentes ayudarán a explicar qué ocurrió realmente.

**Resumen en una frase** – Los científicos podrían haber presenciado un evento raro donde una estrella masiva colapsó directamente en un agujero negro sin explotar, abriendo nuevas ideas sobre cómo terminan las estrellas.
